comments.commentBody:
So agree with all of the comments re: diversionary tactics. The pattern is very clear.

And often I think that only someone who is sneaky and dishonest would think that others are. He is a horrible person.
"He who peers behind closed doors is often found hiding there himself."

If anyone tapped Trump's phones, it was probably the CIA. They were probably aware that Trump set up at least two companies in Cypress, the money-laundering center of the EU that is largely controlled by the Russians. The former president of the Bank of Cypress is Wilbur Ross (now Sec. of Commerce). Ross's friend Josef Ackermann, the infamous banker who was kicked out of Deutschbank for misdeeds, has now found a comfy job in Cypress as Ross's replacement. That same Deutschbank is Trump's biggest lender, and it's also facing a huge fine from the DOJ, where Trump's pick Jeff Sessions is in charge. This whole thing smells to high heaven and points to an increasingly complex web of Russian involvement. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/two-trump-companies-discovered-in-cy...
Cyprus
Yes, you are right. Cyprus. Cypress is what you get when a plant-lover decides to make political comments!
Thanks for the link, Deb. That is one of the most awesomest things I've ever encountered. If we had had that forty years ago, I would have felt differently about chemistry class!

Agree wholeheartedly re the Periodic Table...truly amazing presentation...

Great link, Deb...
Make sure to click on the "Demo" button - it takes you to a YouTube video showing how very clever the site really is.

.
Ugh!

These people who don't use "arete"! So gauche.

Nearly as bad as those who refuse to learn a single thing about sports.

Agree about separating his tweets.  Have a sidebar dealing only with tweets so people can read or ignore as they wish.  Have a box for the tweet(s), then a box to rebut.  Isolate this stuff from front page stories so they become routine and people will get inured to them.  And they won't be considered all that important any more.  And maybe he'll stop.  Or not.

Further proof (as if any were needed) that Trump is mentally unstable. Or, another "shiny object" to distract from the tightening noose of ties to Russia. Either way, let's do with his cabinet members do when abroad, and ignore the crazy orange man in the corner.
Trump has shown over and over again his instability. His recklessness is no longer benign. Trump needs to be impeached. The 25th amendment was made for a POTUS like Trump.

I've got news for rep. Tom Cole - Trump isn't going to make it that much longer.  If Trump thinks the long knives are out for him now, just wait until some of his staffers and appointees start to go rogue.  Trumps head will explode.  Trump is in no way capable of emotionally handling what is about to come at him.  Say what you will about virtually any past President, but they all had nerves of steel when it to being lambasted with accusations and criticism.  Take just GWB and Obama.  Each fairly or unfairly took huge abuse, but they swallowed it, it is a major requirement of the job.  Trump is not only not unable to handle criticism and accusation, he is self destructing over it.  Now, paranoia is starting to flood into him from which there is no return, and this will spell his demise.  He will in a very short time see enemies everywhere, including his own family.  He must be removed from office for our safety.  Trump is a very sick man.

The rational explanation is that he is using Roy Cohn tactics of  'never admit wrongdoing' and then follow-up with 'attack, attack and accuse your accusers of similar or worse doings.' Cohn also taught Trump to follow-up with deflection and spin, too. He regularly uses all Cohn's tactics, and unfortunately, they are effective with his Fox News watching, Brietbart reading base. If you go on the Fox and Friends Facebook page, it is a different world. They all believe Trump's propaganda and they spew it regularly. They also love him to no end. This is one more dangerous lie that Trump is tweeting out there to his brainwashed followers. He and his lies are very, very dangerous.
Comrade Trump's hypocrisy and transparency know no bounds. This man is an embarrassment and a menace to the very fabric of our Nation; and he diminishes all of us, even those who voted for him.

So much for the "Presidential" tone. Could he be more transparent in his effort to deflect attention from his administration and ties with Putin and Co. Has there ever been as much havoc in the infant stages of a Presidency than this one?
"Has there ever been as much havoc in the infant stages of a Presidency than this one?".  In my 67 years, none that I can recall, including Watergate.  But then, Nixon didn't have twitter.
The republicans are scared to death.
Incorrect. The truth is, Trump has a pattern of stating things that are demonstrably untrue. You left that part out.

The president needs psychiatric help and the Republicans know that. Makes you wonder about them. They know he is lying yet they continue to support him because it supports their unholy policies for our country. Are any of these guys Christians? How do they justify themselves as such?
What does "Christian" have to do with them? Ethics, morality--that's what you're talking about. Religious adherence is irrelevant and usually hypocritical.

At this point, it's only a matter of time before the big one hits: clear evidence that Trump has maintained his "business empire" in the 21st century by effectively laundering Russian oligarch money to his properties all over the world. He gets to maintain his self-image, and they get to avoid sanctions. What a deal!

If ever there was a case of the dog catching the car, this is it. I've said it all along: the last thing Trump ever wanted was to ACTUALLY be elected president...And now his nightmare unfolds, and we all get to share in it. Whoops!

Trump is so unstable that it is exceptionally easy for the right-wing media to play him like a violin.

They make baseless accusations and Trump, poster child for mindless impulsivity, writes paranoid tweets.

Trump’s judgment is so alarmingly poor that he doesn’t even have the sense to keep any such bizarre suspicions to himself and his closest advisors; while doing the needed research/consultations to determine their veracity.

Let’s just hope that Bannon, Breitbart and Faux News don’t whisper any nuclear-related little nothings into his ears.

How true.

I was just thinking this morning--before reading this article, even!--that the current so-called president makes George W look like a Rhodes scholar.
ONLY 6 weeks so far? Feels like an eternity. Hope this doesn't last much longer....

What is Trump's problem with McCarthyism? He had close ties with one of the people instrumental in the McCarthy hearings, Roy Cohn, who has been called a Trump mentor. Just more hypocrisy as he tries to distract that there were valid reasons to tap his phone over the Russia connections and not on a whim by Obama.
Nixon was also intrinsic to the McCarthy episode.

As long as it's not mandatory I'm for it. If it's mandatory it's just another "benefit" that cuts into the direct pay. I rather be able to choose a higher hourly wage or that of numerous benefits that cut into that wage. If I opt for parental leave, great, if I opt for sick time, vacation time.. great. However it should be my choice to opt in or out of these benefits. I rather the higher hourly wage be paid upfront, then I will decide where to allocate those funds. Some into a brokerage account that I manage myself, some in a savings account, some in checking. If i need a day off I don't get paid, but the previous days I've worked I got paid higher than what I would initially get if I opted in for sick leave. The same applies for all these various benefits. State I.R.A plans, if mandatory will just cut into the direct wage; then it'll feel like you are getting paid less upfront and people then will demand higher pay..while also continuing to demand more benefits. Automation can't come soon enough.

I worked in a Planned Parenthood clinic years ago and every day, every single patient that I saw I made a positive difference.  Whether it was a basic pap smear screening for general wellness or birth control pills to avoid pregnancies - Planned Parenthood and women's health clinics help women control their health and welfare every single day.  This is not a political statement.  IT is healthcare delivery at its best - there for whomever needs it to be paid by donation or sliding scale.  Nobody is turned away.  And to those who argue that their tax dollars should not go to services with which they morally or politically disagree - I say that is part of living in a democratic society.  My tax dollars fund deadly drone strikes that murder innocent civilians around the world and fund the death penalty here at home.  Both clearly murder - and neither are often protested by the so called pro life crowd.
That's an excellent summation of the hypocrisy of current Republican governance. It'slooks a lot like spray painting graffitti over the Constitution.

Dana, thank you for what you do.  When I worked on a hotline in college Planned Parenthood was at the top of the places we recommended for young women who need contraception, counseling, sex ed, health care, and yes, abortions.  We never heard of anyone having a bad experience with Planned Parenthood.

Obama did not wiretap his phones, the FBI did under a FISA court warrant. Trump has released this information which was previously a secret but is now not due to his statements. He can release the wiretap information but cannot now suppress the release of its findings. Trump made a bad mistake; he is in way over his head. Bannon and Prievus are probably now in Florida trying to concoct some kind of cover-up. The cat is out of the bag and it's name is TREASON.

Don't be like Trump.  Read the Constitution, with particular attention to the definition of treason.  It's very narrow, because the people who wrote it were tired of the British using the word very loosely and then accusing them of it.  Trump is guilty of a lot of things, but treason isn't one of them.
Not Trump, yet. But those around him are skirting with the definition.
The irony is, this tactic was taught to Trump by McCarthy's right-hand-man, Roy Cohn. So much for McCarthyism.

Well, Trump tried to save us from a non-citizen (Obama) from being our President, he warned Republican primary voters that Ted Cruz's dad participated in the assassination of JFK, and he saw with his own eyes  thousands of Muslims celebrating in the streets after 9/11.  And in all the white rural countrysides across America the common folk eat this stuff up and cheer for more.

There is no doubt now whatsoever that despite all that has happened in the ongoing saga of the "Trump Gong Show",  if he stated that he has proof the moon is made of cheese, his supporters would believe him.
Laughable...
